print_settings.Notes:: I printed this with PETG but any material should work. The standoff cap has pretty tight tolerance needs since it is a friction fit. I could easily see different printer/slicer/material settings throwing this off. You might need to play around with that piece for a proper fit.

title: Single screw Drone electronics stack standoff

description.text: I did not feel like waiting for regular standoffs to be shipped so I needed something that could be screwed into the regular single layer standoff and handle multiple layers. This has two different washers. The cap is slightly smaller and is just pressed down to fit. if you want to change the washer size, just increase the Z axis dimension on the print. If anyone is interested in this and needs different dimensions for more layers, then add a comment and I will try to adjust.

Printer Brand:

FlashForge

Printer:

Creator Pro

Resolution:

.2

Notes:

I printed this with PETG but any material should work. The standoff cap has pretty tight tolerance needs since it is a friction fit. I could easily see different printer/slicer/material settings throwing this off. You might need to play around with that piece for a proper fit.

print_settings.Notes:: Band_ETPU.stl and Band_NinjaFlex.stl are one model, the .stl files have the same coordinate axis and can easily be combined in sliver software like simplfy3D, then assign each .stl to one material. BandCapEtpu.stl and BandCapNinjaFlex.stl are also one model.

description.text:
Bioamplifier based on a Raspberry Pi Zero w that streams data to matlab. The project was made at the NIFTy group at the University of Twente as a demonstrator for the IEEE student measurement challange at the IEEE conference in Glasgow in 2017.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Y4tf-qSCpeE&feature=youtu.be

Techinical details can be found on: https://github.com/martijnschouten/raspberry-bioamplifier

Printer Brand:

FlashForge

Printer:

Creator Pro

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.150 mm

Infill:

100%

Notes:

The prints are made on a FlashForge Creator Pro fitted with a Flexion Extruder. The material used is NinjaFlex for the non conductive parts and PI-ETPU 85-700+ (http://palmiga.com) for the conducive parts.

Band_ETPU.stl and Band_NinjaFlex.stl are one model, the .stl files have the same coordinate axis and can easily be combined in sliver software like simplfy3D, then assign each .stl to one material. BandCapEtpu.stl and BandCapNinjaFlex.stl are also one model.

The band contains a custom made bioamplifier and a Raspberry pi zero w to strain the data to a PC running Matlab via WiFi. The code and the schematics of the amplifier are available on: https://github.com/martijnschouten/raspberry-bioamplifier.

Cad drawings are made using Fusion 360.
<iframe allowfullscreen="None" frameborder="0" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/Y4tf-qSCpeE" ></iframe>

G. Wolterink, R. Sanders, F. Muijzer, B.-J. van Beijnum, and G. Krijnen, “3d-printing soft sEMG sensing structures,” 2017. http://palmiga.com
https://flexionextruder.com
https://ninjatek.com
https://github.com/martijnschouten/raspberry-bioamplifier This project has received funding from the European Union’s Horizon 2020 research and innovation programme under grant agreement No. 688857 (SoftPro)

This catapult is designed to be cut out using a lasercutter with 3mm acrylic but should work with 1/8 inch acrylic aswell. It has a mechanical trigger button that can be used to load and fire the catapult.

Some parts might need to be reinforced with glue, for example the bridge parts with rubber bands attached.

The design was made in Autodesk Inventor and was inspired by some other catapults on thingiverse like these:

Hello, I think it's a good idea. Could you tell me what type of sensor or encoder do you use?
Do you control it in Arduino?
comments.author: 3Dadicto

comments.text: I use slot type optocoupler for one directional distance control. Optocoupler output is connected to arduino interrupt pin. When tick is detected, variable is incremented. One full whell turn = 30 ticks. (when detecting only rising or only falling edge)

Highly suggest PETG or Nylon, I printed mine in PETG and it's rock solid and has not loosened in over 20hrs of printing.

Material - PETG or Nylon
Support - No
Infill - 100%

You will need to flip it 180º on the build plate as it's upside down and don't know how to correct it after the model has been drawn. :)

Feel free to leave constructive feedback.

Adjustable Leveling Feet for Ultimaker 2 Series.

I was too lazy to get nuts and bolts from the hardware store so I just whipped up a design with printed ones.

The tolerence between the nut and the bolt is 0 so you have to cut the chamfer on the entry hole and the tip of the bolt.

Put some grease for lubrication or the friction will be too much.

I recommend printing it 100% solid for durability.

Print 2 Lefties, 2 Righties and 4 bolts.

author: LandScan

description.text:
Just a quick solution to provide some diffusion, stand the matrix up and hold the MCU.
Printed in white PLA, I used 0.28mm layer height and plenty of light gets through the single layer front.
2 x 3mm (x 7mm? long) bolts hold the NodeMCU (note: V3 used) to the stand as I wanted a stand alone option for other jobs, the stand holes are 2,5mm and designed to be tapped, the nodemcu part has 3mm holes.
The LED matrix was designed to have a rear but the matrix is a tight fit and is not falling out, need to tug by the wires to remove. Not going to bother for the moment.
This is made for a chinese LED matrix, it uses WS2812B leds on a 10mm pitch exactly, overall matrix size is 80.0 x 80.0mm.

Note I removed the excess wires and resoldered the input wires .. this matrix has a great deal of heat transfer ability (aluminium substrate maybe) and this killed the LED directly under the wires, I had to swap it with the last LED on the matrix, hence the one black corner .. so be warned if you want to resolder these.

Leds as photographed are at around 10% brightness as I am only using a 600mA 5V supply and the matrix full power is 3.5A.

Added the arduion sketch too, its messy as it was a quick hack though others may find it useful, it was originally based on Neofire found on github so that is still in there, but then for the tree I added the neopixel library also and so a constructor exists for both a neomatrix and a neostrand in the same code.
I used OTA so I can upload mods without plugging it into the PC.
Still a work in progress, making the top lights more suitable, fixing stars etc..
Design files are for Designspark Mechanical

print_settings.Notes:: I printed the bracket fro ABS filament, and fused the pieces together with Acetone.

description.text: This mount for the Echo Dot was designed to attached to 1/2" Modular Hose, Loc-Line tube and a clamp so that the Dot can be positioned closer to the user. I designed this for a friend with Multiple Sclerosis who uses the Dot to control his environment, but his voice is weak so the Dot can't always hear him. I used a spring clamp to attach it to his over the bed hospital table so he can use it in his wheelchair or in bed. The I drilled a hole in the clamp for a 1 1/2" long button head cap screw, which was then bolted to a single piece of loc-line with a washer just large enough to fit inside the ball and a nylon lock nut. I experimented a bit with the length of loc-line to figure out the longest length that could support Dot. I ended up settling on 18 links.

description.text:
Nobody's perfect, not even snowflakes.

These six organic snowflake designs were procedurally generated with code in a way that mimics the way that actual snowflakes form as they fall to earth through changing temperature and atmospheric conditions. The code includes random "wiggles" that introduce imperfections into the structure of the flake, creating a stylized, organic form.

Created with our OpenSCAD-fueled Snowflake Machine, which is a free tool that you can also use if you want to create your own custom snowflake designs. To learn how to use the Snowflake Machine, check out the article Tutorial Tuesday 45: Make One Billion Snowflakes With the Snowflake Machine.

title: 1966 Ford GT40  simplified cnc/laser
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
The Ford GT40 Mk2 (GT stands for Gran Tourismo) did win the "24 Hours of Le Mans" four times in a row. The original reason for the development was kind of a revenge of Henry Ford II on Enzo Ferrari for breaking up the negotiations for the sale of Ferrari to Ford.

Using a desktop cnc-machine by Stepcraft with a spiral-toothed 1.5 mm flute I milled the parts from 6.3 mm beech plywood. 5 mm beech rods made the axles, vinyl washers improve the tire movement.

In order to get the tires nice and round I screwed in a m5 bolt and mount it on a drill. Like on a lathe I sanded the surface and rounded the edges.

A laser cutter might be a good alternative tool to create smaller versions.

Visit https://www.zenziwerken.de/en/Toys/Cars for more toy car designs.

author: 3dada

description.text:
This adapter is for a Taz 6 to use a dial gauge to level the 12mm X-Carriage rods to the bed.
(It is a follow on to the Taz 3-5 version: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2675819)

This one clips over the top guide rail, and swings onto the lower rail. the bottom clip has a curvature that locks it well enough to keep it in place.
Use 1/4-20 x 1" or M6 hardware to fasten the dial gauge to the adapter. Make sure to use washers to avoid crushing and loosening, and tighten so it will not move around in use.
I used a 1/4-20 x 1" hex cap screw, a flat washer, lock washer and nut.
This setup makes it easy to correct bed leveling and the Z axis (X carriage rods) transport misalignment.
Move your nozzle height to about 5-10mm above the bed. Turn off the power (or otherwise disable the stepper motors) so you can turn the Z axis screws by hand to level the X carriage.
This can get rid of the binding noise, failure to calibrate and other problems.

author: Cinzoul

title: Tank, Sprockets, Mag Idler Wheels, Suspension Arms

description.text:
These tank track idler wheels go with the tank track 2in, sprockets and other tank related stuff in my things.
Here are several sizes of idler wheels (1.5", 1.75", 2" and 2.25" OD) that will go with the single idler wheel suspension arms for the tank suspension. I think they would be too big to use for the double rollers arms. These use the standard 1/4" x 3/8" x 1/8" sealed ball bearings with shoulder bolts.
When I get the o-ring sizes figured out will list them for you if you want to use them.
Thought the mags looked cool. Thanks and enjoy!

Update: downloaded a mag drive sprocket that uses the standard .770" hub. Also a front idler sprocket and spacers for use with 1/4 x 1-1/2" shoulder bolt. Same bearings as the idlers.
Update: Downloaded another mag drive sprocket2 that corrected some mistakes in the back. I cannot get these to run G-code without errors but they print okay

Update Dec-2017: working on a new tank frame and suspension. Here are the new suspension arms that have the idlers built in. The idea is for the idler to move up and take up the slack in the track from compression. Building a new tank to test it out. Will share the parts in this listing. All of the same parts as the old suspension can be used. Will be listing CNC made frame parts for the new tank on eBay as I get them done.

Update Jan-2018: Downloaded a new 3D printed track tensioner arm for the tanks. This is a 3/4" arm that uses a 1/4" bolt as the shaft, with the bolt hex pressed in the arm to hold arm in place. These can be used with the threaded Fastmike brass bushing I have on eBay to go through the frame. Use a lever with a spring to put tension on the tank track like the original tank. This makes everything work so much better, stiff spring will keep tension arm from giving in reverse. Track tension is a must, but too much greatly increases drag. The tension arm uses 1/4"" x 1" shoulder bolt for the idler sprocket.

Update Feb 2018: Had a hard time printing the 2.25" idler wheels in ABS. Took too long to print and cooling warped them bad. Downloaded a lighter quicker hollow version of the 2.25" idler that prints better and has a support ring and tabs under that comes off after built. These will print without support and save print time. Have not had a chance to test these yet, but the design should hold up just as well.

description.text:
I've designed this to be :

  • easy to print and requires no supports, just orient it flat on the bed
  • perfect for new Tarantula owners using the filament that came in the box
  • minimum additional hardware requirements, only needs a bolt + nut long enough to mount the fan (M3 or M4)

It basically redirects the blower fan thrust at about a 70 degree angle out of 3 vents, so it will work for both single and dual extruder hot ends.

Updates

Hi guys
Something a little different for you this week. This is a mech inspired by Dust Tactics and it is based on a Tiger tank. It doesn't articulate although the turret will turn.
The turret is originally from PRIma so check out his excellent model if your into standard tanks.
I'm working on a series of these so let me know if there's anything you would specifically like to see.
A pretty straightforward print and a good size at 250mm tall (or 10")
As always, have fun with it and don't forget to show your models when your done.
Update 10/1/18 Turret bottom file replaced with repaired one. Thanks to Annatar2 for finding the issue.
Check out my facebook page Bigbangcollectables for more cool models

comments.text: I had some issues with the bottom portion of the turret in Cura. description.text:
A remix of Dakanzla's wonderful magnetic 3D Catan board. I didn't like that the water pieces were were hexagons so I created some flat sided edge pieces. These pieces are designed to fit with Dakanzla's magnetic board.

For a standard board you'll need to print:
6 Water Base
3 Water 1 Harbor
3 Water 2 Harbor

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator+

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Notes:

Printed using the default settings in MakerBot Print. I covered the bed with a layer of painter's tape to prevent delamination.

Parameterized Model in Fusion 360

I created a parameterized envelope for the new pieces using Fusion 360. I grabbed measurements from the original hexagon STLs so the dimensions are probably not a perfect match of the original. I'd be happy to share the source files, just contact me.

Mesh Modeling in Blender

I modeled the waves in Blender and then used a boolean modifier to join it with the parameterized envelope. This was my first time using Blender, but the waves turned out alright. I'd be happy to share the source files, just contact me.

author: jjaco

description.text:
This is the most complex part I have designed so far. It doesn't look all that complicated, but there are a lot of separate pieces of geometry that have to fit together just right in order to make a printable model. The original concept came from an architect who wanted to make a building comprised of multiple curved stories. So I made a number of modifications to that basic design and finally came up with this version. It printed in 19 1/3 hours using a layer height of 0.200 mm and a print speed of 80 mm/sec.

The lamp is designed for an LED "puck" light. Battery operated lights are about $4 each; simply do a web search for "LED puck light" to find several sources. This blog page tells where you can get wall powered lights that are brighter and that work very well: http://birkbinnard.com/blog/wall-powered-led-lights/.

print_settings.Printer:: Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

description.text:
I modified lyshie's mBot hub so we could add some awesome tractor wheels to mbot.

The wheels are from an old (80's) John Deere tractor toy, which my son found in his grandma and grandpa's basement. I must have broken the original toy at least 30 years ago, but the wheels were still cool. :)

The hubs fit very tightly on mBot. Like, be careful pressing them on. But you may not needs screws once they're on.

The 1mm slot and lots of surface area hold the hub to the tractor wheel just fine for this application. Obviously a few drops of CA could make a permanent install for a more powerful vehicle. We're relying on friction for now. The inside of the hole that faces the tractor wheel is flat, but adding a square shaft could make things even tighter, but I didn't have time -- we needed to do a test drive before bedtime!

Printer Brand:

Wanhao

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

30

Notes:

I used rafts and supports because it was hard to get the first, fairly precise layer to stick without, and there's a void that needs to be nice and flat underneath.
You're probably better at 3D printing than I am, so don't take my word for it...
Just mash it on the axle. Mine was very very tight. If you cant get it on the motor's axle, a teeny amount of filing with anything metal might help you out.

description.text:
I've tried to use the one from Spotkiller, but it didn't work out at all for me (misalignment). So I created a new one from scratch.

Just drop into your preferred slicer and hit run. It prints only 1 layer. Added now other forms and a version for regular bed sizes so it's now usable for various printers.

Print time: approx. 08:30 min.

Update 2 (12/2017):

  • Added test for other printer with bed sizes up to 200 mm
  • Added round level test incl. single one
  • Added a circle level test with 4 rings and a text object. You can check for bed adhesion and your quality settings with this too.

Update 1 (11/2017):

  • Added a single square so you can place them by yourself.

Images:

  • 01 Overview
  • 02 Nozzle too close
  • 03 Perfect
  • 04 Nozzle too high
  • 05 Perfect

Printer:

CR-10

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

0%

Notes:

I prefer to use always the same settings for leveling. Yours may differ depending on filament used. 200° C Hotend - 60° Hotbed. Don't do a skirt...

Ho creato questo remix per il modello di cornice quadrata per litofanie creato da smokwithme (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2208146).
Ho riscontrato nei file originali qualche problema di dimensioni e non ruscivo mai a far combaciare perfettamente le colonne stampate a parte come nell'originale. Ho deciso di ridisegnare la base insieme con le colonne in modo da stampare un unico file e sistemato altri piccoli errori dimensionali del precedente. title: Prusa i3 MK3 SolidWorks Assembly (with STEP)

description.text:
UPDATE: 12/22/2017 - Fixed the Frame Thickness to 6.25 mm, which was originally incorrect.
UPDATE: 1/14/2018 - Added new Heatbed Cover. Found in V3.
UPDATE: 2/14/2018 - Added the STEP files for the R2 parts.
UPDATE: 2/17/2018 - Added the SolidWorks Assembly with the R2 parts.

This is a SolidWorks Assembly of the Original Prusa i3 MK3 by Prusa Research.
Since the printed parts on the GitHub are only in SCAD and STL format, this limits what you can do with the parts.
Therefore, a few users on the Prusa Forum and I took the SCAD files and converted them to STEP files using FreeCAD. When they were imported, much of the cutting commands were lost, so I had to manually select the bodies and subtract them.
Made in SolidWorks Student Edition 2017-2018

I have also posted the assembly to GitHub and GrabCAD:

https://github.com/jzkmath/Original-Prusa-i3/tree/MK3

https://grabcad.com/library/prusa-i3-mk3-solidworks-1

I have published this under the same Open-Source Licence as the GitHub licence (GNU-GPL) and I want to give credit where credit is due:
PR Forum members themzlab, dan.d4, martin.m25 for helping convert some of the more difficult files,
Neil Rosenberg from UNC-Asheville Mechatronics for his teaching in SolidWorks while I was in FRC. Also, for providing me with a SolidWorks Assembly of another 3D printer. (which contained the E3D hotend and the Bearings I used)
Josef Prusa and his team at Prusa Research for creating this amazing machine in the first place.

NOTE: if you have a certain format that you need this in, post a comment, and I might be able to add it to the files, if SolidWorks allows!

<iframe allowfullscreen="None" frameborder="0" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/jVcTpP3qqX8" ></iframe>
Using FreeCAD, I was able to convert the OpenSCAD files into STEP, and then SolidWorks format.

A customizable design for a simple faceted container generated by morphing one regular polygon into another. (Technically, the convex hull of the two shapes.) For example, the printed sample has a square bottom and an octagonal top. In addition to the number of sides of the top and bottom polygons, you can customize their radii (to taper the vase instead of expanding it), the height of the vase, and the rotation of the top shape relative to the bottom (useful for aligning different sides). Produces solid models intended to be printed with no infill and no top layers. (If you can't disable top layers, just stop your printer around 90%.)
Part of my Customizable Containers series.
Photos show polygon-morph-vase.stl printed in brown PLA on my Printrbot Simple. 0.15 layer height, 6 bottom layers, 0 top layers, and "spiral vase" mode (1 continuous perimeter).

description.text:
NXPhlite V3RC15

[Includes STEP file source format to allow editing]
This is an enclosure for an experimental flight controller (FMU) from NXP Semiconductor that is Linux Foundation Dronecode.org PX4.io software compliant. It follows Dronecode.org connectorization standards. NXPhlite includes two wire automotive ethernet interfaces and CAN bus in addition to the traditional UARTS, SPI and I2C that is typical of PX4 (Pixhawk) type controllers.

Drone software is NuttX and PX4.io FMU.

The board is based on a Kinetis K66 MCU with 2M memory, and has accelerometer, Gyro, magnetometer, and barometric sensors on board. There are lots of other interfaces (UART, GPS, IRDA, Ultrasonic, PWM, etc) and could easily be used with bare metal code, the Kinetis SDK, and other RTOSs like FreeRTOS.

Suitable for Drones of all configurations, Rovers and other robotic systems.

Credit goes to Herminio Menchaca from the NXP Guadalajara team for the design
Great job Herminio!

This design is a work in progress

Video : https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xLfMEuMjAZE
Documentation : https://www.gitbook.com/book/nxphlite-team/prototype-nxphlite/details
Website: https://www.nxp.com/uav
Website: https://www.nxp.com/HoverGames

Printer:

Raise3D N2

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Infill:

20%

Notes:

There may still be modifications to this model to minimize the amount of support needed.
Printing the top cover on the skinny long edge seems to give the best finish. You just need to pull out the support material from the connector openings.

The bottom shell has little bump-feet. This was designed for injection molding, and this feature is a bit problematic for 3D FDM printing as it causes a very thin support is generated and needed to support the bottom of the lower shell.

comments.author: Stryder2k

comments.text: Just printed the "Bits" base & lid as a test. Unfortunately, the lid is so tight, it's basically unusable. It looks like the interior of the lid is too small, by about the width of one filament. Would you be able to modify the model to address this? Do you have any insight into how you avoided this issue?
comments.author: designbotbot

comments.text:
i thought i had this problem too, but figured i could scale it up by 1% later in CURA, and went on to try the rest.
Found out that all of them are very snug fit, but after a cursory sanding with an emery board, they fit.
The trick i used (for hexagon faction boxes) was to line up the lid on one point, go around the box, and the last two points seem too small. Try pushing in one of the remaining points, and the lid slides down. Push a bit harder (the hex shape makes it surprisingly stronger than it seems, can always reprint if it breaks) on the last point, and the lid snaps down!
Taking them off turned out to be easy (there's a brilliant amount of gap left for the seam between lid and box), and they snap down a bit easier the second time.
I finally went back to the bits box and lid... same trick, a bit more effort, but success!
comments.author: designbotbot

comments.text: Hrm.  It's a tight fit on mine(all the pieces use the same lid fit), but it works ok.  You might want to try scaling the lid up slightly in your slicer by a couple percent.
comments.author: designbotbot

title: Fractional Derivative Graph of an Exponential Function
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: This is a three dimensional graph of e^x, with one axis representing the Riemann-Liouville fractional derivative order ranging from 0 to 1. The x-axis ranges from 0.05 to 1; the fractional derivative of e^x approaches infinity as x approaches 0, hence the axis starts at 0.05. The Riemann-Liouville fractional derivative is continuous with the respect to the order of the derivative, so this graph is nice and smooth.

Printer:

Voron CoreXY

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.15mm

Infill:

20%
You can use super glue to attach the graph to the stand if desired.

I used Mathematica to generate the graph using the included Mathematica code. Then I used Slic3r to scale the Mathematica output to be 80x80x80mm^3 (as well as let it correct some errors in the stl file). Finally, I used Fusion 360 to design the stand.

title: Yosemite's Cathedral Peak super hi res

description.text: This is the most detailed 3d topo I have ever seen. I made it from a LIDAR dataset collected to study nitrogen export and made available on http://opentopo.sdsc.edu/. The LIDAR point cloud was gridded to a 0.5m resolution. You can see the crack systems which make up the popular southeast buttress (5.7) climbing route. You can see Eichorn Pinnacle (5.4). You can see individual trees! You can watch my tutorial video at https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=t4-ICkvyJv0 The print took 11:25. It was sliced with Simplify3d at default high quality settings and printed in PLA on a FlashForge. I also included a larger scale model which shows all of Cathedral Peak for those who are interested. This thing was featured on the 3D Printing Today podcast available on iTunes, Stitcher radio or direct from the source at http://threedprintingtoday.libsyn.com/

this is a guide for the stock Anet a8 extruder. normally the throat of the extruder is almost impossible to get the filament into. this brings the hole closer to the gear and pully so it is easier to get the filament into the hot end. title: Reptile S800 Flight Controller and OLED display holder - Light weight version
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text: This is a light weight version of my original Reptile S800 Flight Controller and OLED display holder https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2680791 (see red print in one of the photos for comparison). I wanted a thing to hold my Flight Controller stack and an OLED display in my Reptile S800 SkyShadow flying wing. I tried to design it to allow room for cables, airflow, and to fit the bay without modification. I think this works pretty well. In my set-up it's holding a PDB, FC, and GPS on the main stack, plus the OLED screen. It fits in the bay and the lid closes without any need for modification. This version weighs around 5g compared to the 8g of the original.

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Mk1

Rafts:

No

No

Notes:

Apologies for the orientation of the object. Fusion 360 had the Y axis set to top by default, I have now remedied this, but for the correct orientation with this print, please rotate the X axis by -90 degrees in your slicer.

I printed this on my Prusa i3 Mk1 in PLA. My settings were:

Brim: 2
Material: 1.75 mm
Nozzle: 0.4
Layer height: 0.20
infill: 15%
Bed temp: 50 C (70 C first layer)
Nozzle temp: 210 C (215 C first layer)
Speed: 40mm/s (60% first layer)
You will need to is chase the M3 threads with a tap. The threads were close to being usable straight off the printer, but the tap makes life much easier.
Designed in Autodesk Fusion 360

description.text: it is cool

EDIT 12/10/17 - Added a version with a smaller hook.

This is a candy cane stocking holder designed to be hung with a Command Strip. The "Candy Cane Hook.stl" file is a single body with some delineation between the segments for easy painting.

I've also included a version of this designed for multi-extruder setups. This one doesn't include the delineation as I assume that you would be printing this in different colors anyways and wouldn't need to paint it. Those bodies for the multi-extruder version are:

  • red-1.stl
  • red-2.stl
  • white-1.stl
  • white-2.stl
  • white-3.stl

Both models include a recessed area on the back for the command strip to sit. This will hopefully allow the rest of the hook to sit closer to the wall. Let me know what you think.

description.text: A recreation of the hard to find Rocket brand pencil sharpener used in G. Harry Stine's and Orville Carisle's original model rocket prototype, circa 1957. This nose cone has been recreated down to the ribs from photographs and old timer's tales. It's sized to fit the Estes BT-50. I've whipped up a cap, for your convenience. Although those would have been carved out of balsa back then. More information on the original rocket here: http://ninfinger.org/rockets/ModelRocketry/Model_Rocketry_v02n08_05-70.pdf
